title: Ontological Paradox: Pumpkin Pirates as the Chasing Marines
theoryText: The Pumpkin Pirates create an ontological paradox by becoming the very Marines who chased the Straw Hat Pirates to Ruluka Island. After escaping the Rainbow Mist and being thrown back in time fifty years, they were rescued by Marines and eventually joined the force. This means they were pursuing themselves in a time loop - the adult Marines who brought the Straw Hats to Ruluka were the same children who the Straw Hats helped rescue from the Rainbow Mist.
author: One Piece Wiki Community
evidenceProvided: The Pumpkin Pirates escape the Rainbow Mist at the end of the arc
They are thrown back in time fifty years to the past
They are rescued by Marines and join the force
Adult Rapanui and the others are shown as the Marines who initially chased the Straw Hats to Ruluka
This creates a closed time loop where the cause and effect are interconnected
counterEvidence: The time travel logic is intentionally vague and not meant to be analyzed deeply
This is a filler arc and not canon to the main story
The mechanics of the Rainbow Mist's time distortion are never fully explained

title: Rainbow Mist as a Temporal Prison
theoryText: The Rainbow Mist functions as an unintentional temporal prison where time flows at a different rate than the outside world. People trapped inside experience only days or weeks while decades pass outside. The space loop property ensures that those inside cannot escape - any attempt to leave just brings them back to their starting point. This explains why ships and their crews have been accumulating in Ape's Concert for potentially centuries, creating the ship graveyard. The phenomenon may be natural or could be a remnant of ancient technology.
author: Arc Analysis Community
evidenceProvided: Fifty years passed outside while the Pumpkin Pirates only aged slightly
Multiple ships from different eras are trapped in Ape's Concert
The space loop property prevents escape by returning everything to its starting point
Robin describes unique temporal properties of the dimension
Henzo spent fifty years researching without finding a natural exit
counterEvidence: The Straw Hats and others eventually do escape, suggesting it's not a perfect prison
The mechanism of time distortion is never scientifically explained
As filler content, the phenomenon's rules may not be fully consistent

title: Continuity Issue: Straw Hats Forget Time Travel
theoryText: The Ruluka Island Arc creates a continuity issue because the Straw Hats experience time travel when they encounter the Pumpkin Pirates (who were displaced in time) and witness the temporal effects of the Rainbow Mist. However, in the canonical Wano Country Arc, the Straw Hats are surprised and confused by the concept of time travel when they meet Momonosuke and learn about Toki's abilities. This suggests either: 1) The Straw Hats don't consider the Rainbow Mist incident as 'true' time travel, 2) They forgot about it, or 3) The filler arc is simply non-canon and doesn't affect their knowledge in the main story.
author: TV Tropes Community
evidenceProvided: Straw Hats witness time distortion in Rainbow Mist Arc
They meet people who have been displaced in time (Pumpkin Pirates)
Later in Wano, they act surprised by time travel despite this experience
The Rainbow Mist Arc is non-canon filler
counterEvidence: As a filler arc, it's not part of the official continuity
The Straw Hats may distinguish between time distortion (slower time) and actual time travel (sending people through time)
Toki's Devil Fruit ability is fundamentally different from the Rainbow Mist phenomenon
